item.title: U.S. Targets Iranâ€™s Petrochemical Industry
item.description: In addition to blacklisting Iranian petrochemical companies for the first time, the Obama administration punished businesses in other countries that help Iran evade oil sanctions.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: Prosecutors Investigate Spending of Government Funds
item.description: Prosecutors in Georgia are investigating allegations that President Mikheil Saakashvili misused government funds, including more than $11,000 for Botox injections.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: U.S. Olympic Leaders Mending Ties With I.O.C.
item.description: The United States Olympic Committee has made changes to satisfy the International Olympic Committee, bolstering a chance to host the 2024 Summer Games.
item.dc:creator: By MARY PILON

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Libya: A Court Seeks Qaddafiâ€™s Son
item.description: Judges at the International Criminal Court ruled that Libya must hand over Seif al-Islam el-Qaddafi, a son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, to the court.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Science and Health: Circumcision Device Approved by World Health Organization
item.description: A nonsurgical circumcision device that relies on a rubber band was approved by the World Health Organization, opening the way for its widespread use in Africa.
item.dc:creator: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Lebanon: Elections Postponed
item.description: Lebanonâ€™s Parliament voted to delay elections, which had been scheduled to take place on June 16, for at least 17 months.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Court Speeds Up Vote
item.description: Zimbabweâ€™s highest court ordered that national elections be held before the end of July, speeding up the expected timetable to choose a new Parliament and hold a presidential vote.
item.dc:creator: By LYDIA POLGREEN

item.title: One Obstacle Wonâ€™t Budge in Japanâ€™s Fight With Deflation
item.description: The Japanese government has made stemming deflation a priority, but its efforts so far have not affected everyday items, like a can of soda.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: Vending machines in Japan have become a stubborn barometer of the countryâ€™s struggle against deflation.

item.title: Michigan Woman Killed in Syria War, Reports Say
item.description: The family and a close friend of Nicole Mansfield said the news delivered by the F.B.I. that she had been in Syria and was killed came as a shock.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON
item.media:credit: Jake May/The Flint Journal, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Carole Mansfield at her home in Burton, Mich., after news that her granddaughter Nicole Mansfield had been killed in Syria.

item.title: U.S. Olympic Leaders Mending Ties With I.O.C.
item.description: The United States Olympic Committee has made changes to satisfy the International Olympic Committee, bolstering a chance to host the 2024 Summer Games.
item.dc:creator: By MARY PILON

item.title: Concern Grows After Group Disappears in Mexico City
item.description: Eleven young people â€” seven men and four women â€” never made it home after a night out in the trendy Zona Rosa neighborhood of the capital.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY
item.media:description: A man looked at posters outside a bar in Mexico City of a group of 11 people that recently disappeared after a night partying.

item.title: Kerry Castigates Russia Over Syria-Bound Missiles
item.description: It was Secretary of State John Kerryâ€™s most pointed criticism so far of Russiaâ€™s supply of weaponry to the Syrian government.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry suggested that Russiaâ€™s continued sale of weaponry to Mr. Assadâ€™s government called into question its commitment to the political process in Syria.

item.title: British Columbia Opposes Planned Oil Sands Pipeline
item.description: Environmental groups said that British Columbia, which has been concerned about spills, has probably doomed the pipeline.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: Taliban Deny Responsibility for Attack on Red Cross
item.description: The Taliban said they had no part in the assault this week on the offices of the International Committee of the Red Cross in Jalalabad, Afghanistan, noting their previous support for the group.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and MATTHEW ROSENBERG

item.title: U.N. Panel Criticizes Russia for Prosecuting Rights Groups
item.description: The chairman of the United Nations Committee Against Torture said legal proceedings had begun against two groups because of reports they sent to the panel.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Economist Sergei Guriev Doesnâ€™t Plan Return to Russia Soon
item.description: Sergei M. Guriev, now teaching at an elite Paris university, said investigators demanded that he surrender five yearsâ€™ worth of e-mails and submit to searches.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Yekaterina Shtukina/RIA Novosti Kremlin, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Sergei Guriev attended a meeting in Moscow in July of last year.

item.title: Amid Recession and Rising Joblessness, Greeks Fall Prey to Employment Swindles
item.description: Authorities say criminals are busy preying on increasingly desperate Greeks facing a deepening recession and a rising unemployment rate.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Small Agreements Between France and Germany Mask Larger Concerns
item.description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany tried to repair a relationship with France, but doubts remained about President FranÃ§ois Hollandeâ€™s resolve to make tough economic decisions.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:credit: Pierre Verdy/Agence France-Presse â€” Getty Images
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President FranÃ§ois Hollande of France in Paris on Thursday, after they agreed on a common approach to the next European Union meeting.

item.title: Special Report: The Female Factor: Charting the Impact of Everyday Sexism Across the World
item.description: A new online project has ballooned into a compendium of first-hand testimonials that range from angry descriptions of patronizing remarks to heart-wrenching accounts of rape and other assault.
item.dc:creator: By BETH GARDINER
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Laura Bates created the Everyday Sexism Project.

item.title: The Female Factor: Ukraineâ€™s Bare-Breasted Feminist Shock Troops
item.description: The women of Femen have elevated nudity as a tool of activism to an Internet-age art form. Their enemies: dictatorship and exploitation.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sasha Shevchenko, a Femen activist, with her mother Lyudmila, who runs a fashion shop in Khmelnytsky.

item.title: Census Shows New Drop in Germanyâ€™s Population
item.description: Already deeply concerned about its rapidly dwindling population, Germany found 1.5 million fewer inhabitants than previously assumed.
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and CHRIS COTTRELL

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Kyrgyzstan Declares State of Emergency After Clashes
item.description: Kyrgyz officials said that 55 people were hurt in a remote northern district when officers dispersed protesters threatening to seize a gold mine.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Eager to Adopt, Evangelicals Find Children, and Pitfalls, Abroad
item.description: A fast-growing Christian movement has revived debate about ethical practices in intercountry adoptions.
item.dc:creator: By ERIK ECKHOLM

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: May 31
item.description: An army recruitment camp in Jammu and Kashmir.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Candidates at an army recruitment camp in Jammu city, Jammu and Kashmir.

item.title: Police Attack Protesters in Istanbulâ€™s Taksim Square
item.description: The police action, with water cannons and tear gas, was the latest crackdown by Turkeyâ€™s government against a movement challenging plans to redevelop a park.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO and CEYLAN YEGINSU
